title: INTERGROWTH-21st Body Composition Equations: Improved
text: following custom functions fit linear models INTERGROWTH-21st body composition standard, print results:
code: #' Extract standard deviation from percentiles #' @param P50 Value of y at mean #' @param PX Value of y at percentile specified by p #' @param p Percentile at which y = PX std_deviation <- function(P50, PX, p) (PX - P50) / qnorm(p = p)  #' Model equation for median (50th centile); print to console #' @param df A dataframe with columns gest_age and P50. Used to fit LM and #' get standard deviation. LM_median <- function(df) {   model <- lm(P50 ~ gest_age, data = df)   std_dev <- mapply(FUN = std_deviation,                      list(df$P50), list(df$P03, df$P10, df$P90, df$P97),                      list(0.03, 0.10, 0.90, 0.97)) |>     median(na.rm = TRUE)   str_model <- paste("y =", coef(model)[[1]], "+",                      coef(model)[[2]], "* x", "+",                      "z * ", std_dev)   str_model }

text: Villar J, Puglia FA, Fenton TR, Ismal LC, Staines-Urias E, Giuliani F, et al. Body composition birth relationship neonatal anthropometric ratios: newborn body composition study INTERGROWTH-21st project Pediatric Research 2017, 82:305-316. doi: 10.1038/pr.2017.52

title: INTERGROWTH-21st Body Composition Equations
text: following custom functions fit linear models INTERGROWTH-21st body composition standard, print results:
code: #' Extract standard deviation from percentiles #' @param P50 Value of y at mean #' @param PX Value of y at percentile specified by p #' @param p Percentile at which y = PX std_deviation <- function(P50, PX, p) (PX - P50) / qnorm(p = p)  #' Get modal values of vector x modes <- function(x) {   ux <- unique(x)   tab <- tabulate(match(x, ux))   ux[tab == max(tab)] }  #' Extract equation and standard deviation; print to console #' @param df A dataframe with columns gest_age, P50 and P90. Used to fit LM and #' get standard deviation. run_LM_extract_eqn <- function(df) {   model <- lm(P50 ~ gest_age, data = df)   str_model <- paste("y =", coef(model)[[1]], "+", coef(model)[[2]], "* x")   stddev_90 <- std_deviation(df$P50, df$P90, p = 0.9)   str_stddev <- paste("sigma at P90 =", round(mean(modes(stddev_90)), digits = 4))   cat(c(str_model, str_stddev), sep = "\n") }

title: Assess Growth in Infants and Newborns
text: Produced part Guidance International Growth Standards project, gigs provides single, simple interface working Child Growth Standards outputs INTERGROWTH-21st project. find functions converting anthropometric measures (e.g. weight length) z-scores percentiles, inverse. Also included functions classifying newborn infant growth according DHS guidelines.

title: Assess Growth in Infants and Newborns
code: # Install the development version from GitHub: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("lshtm-gigs/gigs")

title: Assess Growth in Infants and Newborns
text: wfga - Weight (kg) gestational age (days) lfga - Length (cm) gestational age (days) hcfga - Head circumference (cm) gestational age (days) wlrfga - Weight--length ratio gestational age (days) fmfga - Fat mass (g) gestational age (days) bfpfga - Body fat percentage gestational age (days) ffmfga - Fat-free mass (g) gestational age (days) wfa - Weight (kg) post-mentstrual age (weeks) lfa - Length (cm) post-mentstrual age (weeks) hcfa - Head circumference (cm) post-mentstrual age (weeks) wfa Weight (kg) age (days) bfa Body mass index age (days) lhfa Length/height (cm) age (days) wfl Weight (kg) recumbent length (cm) wfh Weight (kg) standing height (cm) hcfa Head circumference (mm) age (days) acfa Arm circumference (mm) age (days) ssfa Subscapular skinfold (mm) age (days) tsfa Triceps skinfold (mm) age (days)

title: Assess Growth in Infants and Newborns
text: Conversion functions named according set standards use, component standard set, type conversion. example, convert values z-scores weight--GA standard INTERGROWTH-21st Newborn Size Standards : ig_nbs/_wfga/_value2zscore() Similarly, conversion length--age values centiles term preterm infants performed Child Growth Standards INTERGROWTH-21st Post-natal Growth Preterm Infants Standards, respectively: Term infants: who_gs/_lhfa/_value2zscore() Preterm infants: ig_nbs/_lfa/_value2percentile() component standard included function call, passed acronym parameter general function call. vector acronym values can used want convert different standards input.

title: Assess Growth in Infants and Newborns
text: functions allow easy conversion measured values z-scores percentiles standard used.
code: # Convert from z-scores for individual values... ig_nbs_value2zscore(y = 0.785, gest_age = 182, sex = "F", acronym = "wfga") |>         round(digits = 2) #> [1] 0  # .. or for multiple inputs ig_nbs_wfga_value2percentile(weight_kg = 0.785, gest_age = seq(175, 196, by = 7), sex = "F") |>         round(digits = 2) #> [1] 0.75 0.50 0.25 0.09  # You can do the same for percentiles ig_png_wfa_value2percentile(weight_kg = c(2.86, 3.12, 3.12, 3.43, 3.77, 4.10),                             pma_weeks = 40,                             sex = "M") |>         round(digits = 2) #> [1] 0.10 0.25 0.25 0.50 0.75 0.90

title: Assess Growth in Infants and Newborns
text: functions convert z-scores expected anthropometric measurements. mostly useful creation reference curves (see ).
code: # Convert from z-scores for individual values... ig_nbs_zscore2value(z = 0, gest_age = 182, sex = "F", acronym = "wfga") |>         round(digits = 3) #> [1] 0.785  # .. or for multiple inputs ig_nbs_wfga_zscore2value(z = 0, gest_age = seq(182, 204, by = 7), sex = "F") |>         round(digits = 3) #> [1] 0.785 0.893 1.013 1.147  # You can do the same for percentiles ig_png_wfa_percentile2value(p = c(0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.9),                             pma_weeks = 40,                             sex = "M") |>         round(digits = 2) #> [1] 2.87 3.12 3.43 3.77 4.11

title: Assess Growth in Infants and Newborns
text: can use gigs generate reference curves standards getting curves expected weight multiple z-scores across multiple gestational ages. usually recommend ggplot2 visualisation, use reduce package’s dependencies.
code: z_score_range <- -2:2 gestage_range <- 168:230 ref <- mapply(z_score_range,              FUN = function(z) {                gigs::ig_nbs_wfga_zscore2value(z = z,                                         gest_age = gestage_range,                                         sex = "F")              }) matplot(ref, x = gestage_range, col = 1:5, type = "l", lty = 2:6,         xlab = "Gestational age (days)",         ylab = "Weight (kg)") title(main = "Weight-for-GA in very preterm newborns") legend(x = min(gestage_range) + 1, y = ref[length(ref)], legend = 2:-2,        title = "Z-score", col = 5:1, lty = 2:6)

title: Assess Growth in Infants and Newborns
text: functions allow quick identification -risk infants classification suboptimal growth. cut-offs used sourced research literature; can check function documentation see sources.
code: # Size for gestational age classify_sga(         weight_kg = c(2.5, 3.2, 4.0),         gest_age = 277,         sex = "M" ) #> [1] SGA AGA LGA #> Levels: SGA AGA LGA  # Stunting, i.e. low length increase relative to age classify_stunting(         lenht_cm = c(42.3, 75.4, 72.83),         age_days = c(252, 525, 245),         ga_at_birth = c(238, 259, 266),         sex = "M",         lenht_method = "H" ) #> [1] implausible stunting    normal      #> Levels: implausible stunting_severe stunting normal  # Wasting, i.e. low weight increase relative to length/height classify_wasting(         weight_kg = c(5.75, 2.18, 5.30, 6.75),         lenht_cm = c(67.7, 46.6, 55.8, 80.1),         sex = c("F", "M", "F", "M"),         lenht_method = c("H", "L", "L", "H") ) #> [1] wasting_severe wasting        normal         implausible    #> Levels: implausible wasting_severe wasting normal overweight  # Weight-for-age, i.e. low weight increase relative to age classify_wfa(         weight_kg = c(2.1, 7.2, 6.1, 9.1, 9.4),         age_days = c(435, 501, 323, 201, 154),         ga_at_birth = c(36, 27, 37, 40, 28),         sex = c("M", "M", "F", "F", "F") ) #> [1] implausible        underweight_severe underweight        normal             #> [5] overweight         #> Levels: implausible underweight_severe underweight normal overweight

Investigation Management Small--Gestational-Age Fetus: Green-top Guideline . 31. Technical report, Royal College Obstetricians Gynaecologists, London, 2013.

title:
Classify size for gestational age using INTERGROWTH-21st Newborn Size

code: # Without coarse flag, does not differentiate between p < 0.03 and p < 0.10 classify_sga(   weight_kg = c(2.2, 3.4, 4.2),   gest_age = 267,   sex = "F" ) #> [1] SGA AGA LGA #> Levels: SGA AGA LGA  # With coarse = FALSE, highlights p < 0.03 classify_sga(   weight_kg = c(2.2, 3.4, 4.2),   gest_age = 267,   sex = "F",   coarse = FALSE ) #> [1] SGA(<3) AGA     LGA     #> Levels: SGA(<3) SGA AGA LGA

text: lenht_cm Length/height measurement(s) cm. age_days Age(s) days child. ga_at_birth Gestational age(s) birth days. sex Sex(es), either "M" (male) "F" (female). lenht_method "H" "L" value(s) describing whether lenht_cm recorded recumbent length #' standing height. NA values set "L" children <731 days old "H" children 731 days old . Default = NA.

title:

standards — classify_stunting
text: guidelines stipulate recumbent length measured 730 days. Therefore recumbent #' length values children 730 days old 0.7 cm taken away, height values children less 731 days old 0.7 cm added . Implausible z-scores sourced referenced report, classification criteria DHS manual.

title: Convert anthropometric measures to WHO Growth Standards z-scores — who_gs_value2zscore
code: # Convert values to percentiles who_gs_value2percentile(y = 10.1, x = 505, sex = "M", acronym = "wfa") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 0.32  # Or values to z-scores who_gs_value2zscore(y = 10.1, x = 505, sex = "M", acronym = "wfa") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] -0.48  # Specify which standard to use with the acronym parameter... who_gs_value2percentile(y = 75.2, x = 300, sex = "M", acronym = "lhfa") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 0.82  # ... or by using a standard-specific function who_gs_lhfa_value2percentile(lenht_cm = 75.2, age_days = 300, sex = "M") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 0.82  # Inputs are recycled to the input of the longest length who_gs_ssfa_value2percentile(subscap_sf_mm = 6.1,                              age_days = seq(450, 650, by = 50),                              sex = "M") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 0.44 0.47 0.50 0.52 0.54  # Bad inputs will not stop the function but will instead return NA - here # 121 cm for height_cm is incompatible with the WHO Growth Standard for # weight-for-height who_gs_wfh_value2zscore(weight_kg = c(7.4, 14.2, 21.8, 22.4),                         height_cm = c(65, 95, 120, 121),                         sex = "M") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] -0.05  0.12 -0.27    NA

code: # Convert percentiles to values p <- 0.25 # 25th percentile who_gs_percentile2value(p = p, x = 501, sex = "M", acronym = "wfa") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 9.86  # Or z-scores to values z <- qnorm(p) who_gs_zscore2value(z = z, x = 501, sex = "M", acronym = "wfa") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 9.86  # Specify which standard to use with the acronym parameter... who_gs_zscore2value(z = z, x = 300, sex = "M", acronym = "lhfa") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 71.56  # ... or by using a standard-specific function who_gs_lhfa_zscore2value(z = z, age_days = 300, sex = "M") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 71.56  # Inputs are recycled to the input of the longest length who_gs_ssfa_percentile2value(p = seq(0.1, 0.9, by = 0.2),                              age_days = 670,                              sex = "M") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1] 4.81 5.45 5.97 6.58 7.66  # Bad inputs will not stop the function but will instead return NA - here 60 # cm for height_cm is incompatible with the WHO Growth Standard for # weight-for-height who_gs_wfh_zscore2value(z = 0,                         height_cm = c(60, 85, 105, 120),                         sex = "M") |>   round(digits = 2) #> [1]    NA 11.67 16.85 22.35
